text: I vaguely recall an announcement on discourse a couple of months ago, of a package that attempted to provide a posterior distribution over the optimal solution to an optimization problem after it had been solved, using only the loss function and the optimal solution. I can't seem to find the post announcing it, and wonder if anyone here might know what I'm talking about?

elements.text: I vaguely recall an announcement on discourse a couple of months ago, of a package that attempted to provide a posterior distribution over the optimal solution to an optimization problem after it had been solved, using only the loss function and the optimal solution. I can't seem to find the post announcing it, and wonder if anyone here might know what I'm talking about?

text:
After a couple of hours searching, here it is :heart_eyes:
<https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ann-minimallydisruptivecurves-jl-regional-in-sensitivity-analysis-by-finding-hidden-relationships-between-model-parameters/47873?u=baggepinnen|https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ann-minimallydisruptivecurves-jl-regional-in-sensitivity-analysis-by-finding-hidden-relationships-between-model-parameters/47873?u=baggepinnen>

attachments.title: [ANN] MinimallyDisruptiveCurves.jl : regional (in)sensitivity analysis by finding hidden relationships between model parameters
attachments.text: Hi all! Made a new package for nonlocal sensitivity analysis, which extends this algorithm. A full user guide, with motivation, examples and jupyter notebooks is here: <https://dhruva2.github.io/MinimallyDisruptiveCurves.docs/> What does it do? You’ve already fitted some model, by minimising a cost function on the model behaviour. Any type of model, as long as the cost function is differentiable. (I’ve focused on ODE models of biological processes in the user guide). This tool solve...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: [ANN] MinimallyDisruptiveCurves.jl : regional (in)sensitivity analysis by finding hidden relationships between model parameters
